hypotheses.title: Lazarus Group Medusa Ransomware Deployment via Compromised Healthcare and Social Services Infrastructure
hypotheses.description: Lazarus Group has adopted Medusa ransomware in targeted attacks against healthcare and social services organizations in the U.S. and Middle East. Based on recent incidents, attackers likely gain initial access via supply chain compromise, phishing, or exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities (e.g., BeyondTrust CVE-2026-1731). We should hunt for Medusa-specific artifacts, lateral movement via legitimate remote access tools, and ransomware execution patterns.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs, command-line arguments, file creation/modification timestamps, registry modifications, memory dumps
Outbound connections to C2 domains/IPs, encrypted traffic to unusual destinations, SMB traffic to non-standard hosts
Unusual RDP/SSH logins, privilege escalation events, MFA bypass attempts, anomalous service account usage
tools: Azure AD Audit Logs, Okta, CrowdStrike Falcon Identity

hunting_tactics.description: Search for Medusa-specific file artifacts, command-line flags, and encryption behavior
sample_queries: event.type:file AND (file.name:*medusa* OR file.path:*\medusa* OR file.extension:*.medusa)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Files with .medusa extension, README files referencing Medusa, suspicious rundll32.exe usage with Medusa-related arguments

hunting_tactics.description: Detect exploitation of the actively exploited BeyondTrust flaw used to deploy VShell and gain persistence
sample_queries: process.parent_name:svchost.exe AND process.command_line:*-i -c* AND process.current_directory:*\Program Files\BeyondTrust*
hunting_tactics.look_for: VShell execution, svchost.exe spawning SSH clients with interactive flags, unexpected SSH connections from domain controllers

hunting_tactics.description: Identify post-exploitation credential harvesting and movement using legitimate remote access tools
sample_queries: event.action:connection AND network.connection.dest_port:445 AND process.name:svchost.exe AND process.command_line:*lsass*
hunting_tactics.look_for: Mimikatz usage, PsExec with SYSTEM token, LSASS access via svchost.exe

network_patterns: Unusual HTTPS to Eastern Europe or North Korea IP ranges
other_indicators: Unusual RDP sessions from non-standard locations

recommended_actions: Isolate affected hosts immediately upon detection
Reset credentials for all compromised accounts
Review BeyondTrust configurations and apply patches (CVE-2026-1731)
Scan for Medusa ransomware artifacts across all endpoints and file shares

hypotheses.title: ClickFix Social Engineering Campaigns Delivering MIMICRAT, CastleLoader, and LummaStealer via Fake CAPTCHA and nslookup DNS Tunneling
hypotheses.description: ClickFix threat actors have evolved their social engineering tactics to include DNS tunneling via nslookup commands and abuse of Google Ads, Claude AI, and compromised websites to deliver infostealers like MIMICRAT, CastleLoader, and LummaStealer. We should hunt for signs of these evolving delivery mechanisms, especially in endpoints with PowerShell, nslookup, and browser-based command execution.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1059.003 - Command Shell: Windows Command Shell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: PowerShell command-line logs, nslookup execution, browser process spawning unusual child processes, file creation in temp directories
tools: Sysmon, Elastic EDR, Microsoft Defender ATP

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries with long encoded subdomains, HTTP requests to Pastebin/Google Sites, suspicious Google Ad redirects
tools: Zeek DNS logs, Cisco Umbrella, Palo Alto URL filtering logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Phishing emails with fake CAPTCHA links, malicious attachments, or Google-hosted payloads
tools: Mimecast, Proofpoint, Microsoft Defender for Office 365

hunting_tactics.description: Detect nslookup abuse for malware staging via DNS TXT record parsing
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup.exe with encoded TXT queries, nslookup piped to PowerShell/cmd, nslookup used in command chains

hunting_tactics.description: Identify PowerShell scripts used in ClickFix campaigns to download and execute payloads
sample_queries: process.name:powershell.exe AND process.command_line:*-w hidden* AND process.command_line:*net user*
process.parent_name:cmd.exe AND process.name:powershell.exe AND process.command_line:*-nop* AND process.command_line:*-noni*
hunting_tactics.look_for: Encoded PowerShell with base64, hidden PowerShell launching net user/net view, non-interactive PowerShell from cmd.exe

hunting_tactics.description: Search for MIMICRAT-specific indicators and CastleLoader loader behavior
hunting_tactics.look_for: CastleLoader persistence in Startup folder, MIMICRAT/ModeloRAT process execution, registry run keys for castleloader

network_patterns: HTTP requests to Pastebin/Google Sites with long encoded payloads
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/120.0.0.0 Safari/537.36
other_indicators: Google Ads redirecting to fake Zoom/Captcha pages
Fake Claude AI guides with malicious links

recommended_actions: Block nslookup.exe from executing with encoded queries
Review PowerShell script block logging for encoded commands
Hunt for CastleLoader persistence mechanisms across endpoints
Update EDR signatures for MIMICRAT and LummaStealer

hypotheses.title: SmartLoader and VoidLink Framework Campaigns Targeting AI Infrastructure and Financial Services via Supply Chain Compromise
hypotheses.description: SmartLoader has been observed cloning legitimate Oura MCP servers to distribute StealC infostealer, while UAT-9921 uses the modular VoidLink framework to target technology and financial organizations. We should hunt for signs of AI agent compromise (OpenClaw, MCP servers), supply chain abuse in npm/PyPI, and modular malware deployment patterns.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.001 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1565.001 - Data Manipulation: Stored Data Manipulation

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Python process execution, OpenClaw configuration file access, MCP server connections, file deletion events
Connections to MCP servers, npm/PyPI package downloads, suspicious API calls to cloud services
tools: Zeek, Palo Alto Networks, Cisco Stealthwatch

data_sources_needed.specific_data: IAM role changes, S3 bucket access logs, Lambda function deployments
tools: AWS CloudTrail, Azure AD Audit Logs, GCP Cloud Logging

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: OpenClaw and AI Agent Configuration Theft
hunting_tactics.description: Detect infostealer attempts to exfiltrate OpenClaw configuration and identity files
hunting_tactics.look_for: Access to .clawdbot, .openclaw, or .clawdbot directories, StealC targeting OpenClaw config files, Python processes accessing OpenClaw directories

hunting_tactics.description: Identify fake Oura MCP servers used in SmartLoader campaigns
hunting_tactics.look_for: Python processes referencing 'ouramcp' with suspicious arguments, MCP servers on non-standard ports, registry keys with 'fork' references

hunting_tactics.description: Search for modular VoidLink framework components and UAT-9921 indicators
hunting_tactics.look_for: VoidLink-related processes, voidloader.exe spawned from cmd.exe, temp directories with voidlink naming

network_patterns: Connections to MCP servers on port 8080/443
npm/PyPI package downloads from non-standard registries
API calls to cloud services from non-cloud hosts
other_indicators: Fake forks/contributors on GitHub for Oura MCP

recommended_actions: Hunt for OpenClaw configuration files across endpoints and cloud storage
Monitor Python processes for suspicious MCP server activity
Review npm/PyPI package history for SmartLoader-related compromises
Isolate hosts with OpenClaw configuration exfiltration attempts

hypotheses.title: ShinyHunters Data Extortion Campaigns Targeting Customer Data via Credential Stuffing and Third-Party Vendor Compromise
hypotheses.description: ShinyHunters has been actively targeting organizations across multiple sectors, including fintech (Figure), automotive (CarGurus), telecom (Odido), and fashion (Canada Goose). Attacks often involve credential stuffing, employee phishing, or third-party vendor compromise. We should hunt for signs of credential reuse, suspicious data exfiltration to known leak sites, and patterns of credential harvesting preceding data breaches.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Failed login attempts, credential stuffing patterns, MFA bypass attempts, unusual geographic logins
tools: Azure AD Identity Protection, Okta Risk-Based Policies, CrowdStrike Falcon Identity

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Large data transfers to external IPs, connections to known leak sites, suspicious email exfiltration
Phishing emails impersonating internal services, fake SSO login pages
tools: Microsoft Defender for Office 365, Mimecast, Proofpoint

hunting_tactics.description: Detect credential stuffing patterns targeting customer and employee accounts
sample_queries: event.action:login_failure AND user.email:*@* AND event.outcome:failure AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:authentication
event.action:login AND user.email:*@* AND source.ip:* AND event.outcome:success AND event.dataset:authentication AND event.dataset:login
user.name:* AND event.action:login_failure AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:authentication AND event.dataset:login
hunting_tactics.look_for: High volume of login failures from same IP, successful logins after multiple failures, logins from unusual locations after failures

hunting_tactics.description: Search for connections to ShinyHunters' leak infrastructure and data transfer patterns
hunting_tactics.look_for: Connections to known ShinyHunters domains/IPs, large file transfers to external domains, files named 'shinyhunters_data.zip' or similar

hunting_tactics.description: Identify signs of compromise via third-party vendors (e.g., Salesforce, SSO providers)
sample_queries: event.action:api_call AND user.name:*service_account* AND event.dataset:api AND event.dataset:oauth
event.action:login AND user.email:*@* AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:authentication AND event.dataset:login AND event.dataset:oauth
hunting_tactics.look_for: Service account API calls to Salesforce/Okta, Python scripts accessing Salesforce APIs, OAuth token abuse from non-standard locations

network_patterns: Connections to leak sites at unusual times
Email exfiltration via SMTP to non-standard ports
other_indicators: Fake SSO login pages impersonating Okta/Microsoft
Phishing emails with 'Security Incident Report' PDFs

recommended_actions: Enforce MFA for all customer and employee accounts
Review and restrict third-party API access (Salesforce, Okta)
Monitor for large data exfiltration to known leak sites
Hunt for credential stuffing patterns in identity logs

hypotheses.title: AI-Powered FortiGate Compromise Campaigns Using AI-Assisted Scanning and Weak Credentials
hypotheses.description: A Russian-speaking threat actor used commercial generative AI tools to compromise over 600 FortiGate firewalls across 55 countries by exploiting exposed management ports and weak credentials. We should hunt for signs of AI-assisted scanning, unauthorized FortiGate access, and lateral movement from compromised firewalls to internal networks.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

data_sources_needed.specific_data: FortiGate management port access (TCP 8443/443), failed login attempts, SSH connections from non-standard hosts
FortiClient process execution, unusual SSH sessions, firewall rule changes
FortiGate logs, configuration changes, session logs, API access logs

hunting_tactics.description: Detect AI-assisted scanning patterns targeting FortiGate management interfaces
sample_queries: network.connection.dest_port:8443 AND network.connection.dest_port:443 AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:connection AND event.dataset:firewall
network.connection.dest_port:8443 AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:connection AND event.dataset:firewall AND event.dataset:dns
hunting_tactics.look_for: Rapid sequential connections to port 8443 from same IP, Python scripts scanning FortiGate ports, DNS queries for FortiGate-related domains

hunting_tactics.description: Identify unauthorized access to FortiGate management interfaces
sample_queries: event.action:login AND user.name:*admin* AND source.ip:* AND event.dataset:firewall AND event.dataset:fortigate
hunting_tactics.look_for: Failed admin logins, successful logins from non-standard IPs, configuration changes without approval

hunting_tactics.description: Search for lateral movement from compromised firewalls to internal networks
hunting_tactics.look_for: SSH from FortiGate to internal hosts, port forwarding via SSH, Python scripts accessing internal network ranges

network_patterns: SSH from FortiGate to internal hosts
Connections to internal networks from FortiGate IP
other_indicators: FortiGate configuration changes at unusual times
New admin accounts created without approval

recommended_actions: Disable FortiGate management interfaces from public access
Enforce strong passwords and MFA for all admin accounts
Monitor FortiGate logs for configuration changes and unauthorized access
Hunt for lateral movement from FortiGate to internal networks

unique_mitre_techniques: T1059.003 - Command Shell: Windows Command Shell
T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1565.001 - Data Manipulation: Stored Data Manipulation
T1195.001 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
